Dear Jennifer Keller:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area Manager at 860-0787

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
2023C0000193
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201514
Licensee Group Organization: Wolverine Human Services
Licensee Designee: Judith Wollack
Chief Administrator: Jennifer Keller
Agency Name: Wolverine Humans Services Aftercare
Agency Address: 20300 Superior Rd
Ste 140
Taylor, MI 48180-6302
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 11/29/2023
Capacity:

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12202- Policy and procedures.
Section (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for all of the following:
(a) Financial stability.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are current financial stability concerns related to the agency
due to a 9.4-million-dollar debt.
Investigation Interviews:
Audit/Review Manager X
On 1/26/2023 I had an email correspondence with Audit/Review
Manager X related to the document received via the complaint
receipt source. Review Manager X provided advisement with
respect to my special investigation exploration.
Agency Staff:
Entrance Conference/ Chief Operating Officer 3
On 2/3/2023 I meet with Chief Administrator 1(who was the chief
administrator at the onset of this special investigation),
3

Administrator 2, and Chief Operating Officer (COO) 3 related to
the allegations. COO 3 was the spokesperson during this meeting.
I also had email correspondence with COO 3 on 2/28/2023.
We discussed the financial concern allegation as
documented/outlined by a 1/11/2023 Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services (MDHSS) Audit and Review
Memorandum related to Wolverine Human Services’ fiscal year
2021 review. This memorandum referenced Notes number 5 and
12 from the agency’s 2021 Financial Audit, related to possible
financial instability for the agency.
COO 3 voiced concern as to why this complaint allegation came
through related to Wolverine’s child placing agency (CPA)license
when the debt in question relates to the organization’s prior child
caring institution (CCI) license. COO 3 advised he had addressed
this complaint matter with DCWL’s (Division of Child Welfare
Licensing) Director XX, as to why DCWL was connecting this CPA
license to the allegation. He said, Director XX reported, it was
easier to address the complaint matter this way. COO 3 reported
the Department had been aware of the agency’s challenges,
because the agency’s program losses have been expressed with
the Department yearly, especially during COVID. He reported the
agency surrendered its Wolverine Secure Treatment Center
(WSTC) program’s license in 2021. He reported the bulk of the
debt this allegation relates connects to the WSTC building which,
the agency stop paying on after the secure juvenile justice
program closed down. He said the agency is trying to sell or
made other arrangements for that building. He said, they have had
different companies from various states (Kentucky, Ohio, etc.) to
look at the building, but the companies either pulled out or nothing
came to be.
COO 3 reported the 9.4-million-dollar debt this special
investigation alleges, is really more like 7 million dollars. He
reported of that total, 3 million is owed to one lender, Comerica-
Bank; and that will be paid off in March or May of this year (2023).
He advised they could not pay off early-because that would incur
penalties. He reported with respect to the loan for the WSTC
building, that project was a community venture. He reported the
parties, bonds, changed over the year, but the facility was a joint
venture built for MDHHS, etc. He reported due to the Department
being a part of the team, Wolverine was trying to work things out
related to that building. He reported, losses, such as inequities in
services cost (especially during COVID); a lack of payment when
children go home; CWTI (Child Welfare Training institute) not
4

being paid for; all contributed to that debt. He reported there had
been an agreement to not do anything with the WSTC building for
five years; and Wolverine offered it up as a possible resource for
the Department. For example, possibly converting the WSTC
building over to some other program for children, such as a
residential shelter; but apparently there are no fees for such. He
said the agency has made a verbal commitment to the contract
piece related to this WSTC property, but things have not been
working out.
COO 3 reported that what’s on paper related to the alleged 9.4-
million-dollar debt also does not take into account other funds
coming into the agency. Such as 3.4 million dollars that the
Department sent; over 2 million dollars that will be forth coming
related to employment retention that is a part of their 2–3-year
operational cost; and the Department’s daily rate increases.
Additionally, COO 3 reported what should be taken into account
by DCWL is that the agency made foster parent/board and care
payments regardless as to whether State checks came to the
agency timely. He reiterated, Wolverine pays its foster care
providers; payments from the State for these services go directly
to the providers, not an agency accounts. He further reported a
desire for the State to recognize the services costs that are
connected to issues pertaining to agencies’ finances/debts. He
reported investigations like this one seem to serve to penalize the
agency over some financial woes; and that there really should be
some kind of financial protections coming from the Department.
He acknowledged it’s true that the agency’s foster program has to
support other programs, is paying for other agency costs, but
Wolverine is not going into bankruptcy. And notwithstanding the
agency electing to allow the loan for the WSTC building to default,
the agency’s other debts, leases are being taken care of. He
reported with respect to the actual 7-million-dollar debt owed on
the WSTC loan, Wolverine has frequent contact/ ongoing
communications with the lender, as they work towards a mutual
solutions; whether that’s a sale or new usage of that the building.
COO 3 reported they are following the financial guidance of their
legal advisors, but the objective is to resolve the debt. This has
been reported to many DHHS directors, legislators, courts,
business groups etc. He said, the agency has and will continue to
work with interested parties who explore that property. That
Wolverine’s efforts related to that debt is not preventing them from
doing business, or paying other lenders, as they, as a nonprofit,
are navigating the financial difficulties of a pandemic, and the
changes in the array in services.
5

Administrator 2
I spoke with Administrator 2, the Executive Director of Community-
Based Programs and current chief administrator for this license,
by telephone on 4/19/2023. Administrator 2 reported various
statements as reported by COO 3 or as represented in documents
provided by Administrator 4. These being that the agency is
paying its bills, as well as caregivers and staff. The reported 9.4-
million-dollar debt referenced in the complaint is by way of two
lenders. The smaller loan is via Comerica Bank. Administrator 2
believed the balance on that loan is $58,762.00, which will be paid
off by 5/1/2023. She reported Administrator 4 could better
address this matter. The larger loan is by way of Investco, the
company that holds the mortgage on the WSTC building that went
into default in 2021. The current balance on that loan was
$6,078,110 and Wolverine’s legal fiscal team is working with
Investco to resolve that matter.
Administrator 4
On 4/24/2023, I interviewed Administrator 4, Wolverine’s Lead
Financial Controller. Administrator 4 had also provided me prior
email documents as indicated in the methodology section of this
report. The documents related to the agency’s loan payments,
staff and caregiver payments, and utilities and various agency
buildings’ lease payments. Administrator 4 clarified some reporting
by Administrator 2 and affirmed some reporting by COO 3. Those
being that the agency is paying its financial obligations and is not
struggling to meet those obligations. Administrator 4 reported
that all of Wolverine’s Community Based Program buildings are
leases. These offices are located in Warren, Flint, Bloomfield, and
Taylor Michigan respectively. The leases’ origination dates and
monthly lease payment amounts are as follow:
Lease Holder Lease date Payment amount
LSPV Cornerstone- LLC 1/17/2017 $5,103.28
Flint, MI
F & M Company LLC- 8/1/2017 $7,094.62
Warren, MI
20300Superior- Taylor, 3/17/2016 $22,576.00
MI
Manabal Eastwood- 9/15/2015 $5, 423. 00
Bloomfield, MI
Utilities are paid directly to the Leaser for Taylor. There were also
being paid that way for the Bloomfield office. The Bloomfield lease
ended 3/31/2023; the agency did not renew it. That office was
rarely used by staff; and staff now utilize the Flint office, if needed.
6

Administrator 4 provided me a payment history for leases and
utilities from 10/01/2020 to March 2023. Payments were
documented as consistent and timely; no concerns were noted or
indicated.
Administrator 4 reported the agency has had several loans
through the years. The agency has had three major loans with
Comerica Bank in the last few years. One loan related to a
$350,000 loan the agency took out in December of 2017 for wiring
and development on various community-based program offices.
This loan was paid off in November of 2022. Documentation from
Administrator 4 showed this loan listed on Comerica Bank notices
as Note # 000-00-0013-3. As of a 11/30/2022 Comerica Bank
Loan payment notice, $55.69 for interest was listed on that
account.
The other two Comerica Bank loans relate to completion of a gym
and other constructions or improvements on Wolverine’s Vassar
Campus (another CCI licensed program). The smaller of these
two loans was paid off on 4/10/2023. Administrator 4 provided me
a copy of the Comerica Bank statement showing that loan’s pay
off. A 4/10/2023 Comerica statement showed a $18, 244.13
principal balance; $26.07 interest balance, and indicated a
$18,270.20 loan pay off (Comerica Loan Detroit Reference#
98953387870- Note # 000-00-003-4). The second of these two
loans was refinanced a couple of years ago. The amount was $3.
3 million dollars; and the current balance as of 4/11/2023 is
$2,415,960.80(Note # 000-0015-8). This balance came to be after
Wolverine made an additional payment on 04/11/2023 of
$6,700.00, which reduces the principal balance to the
2,415,960.80 amount. Administrator 4 reported the monthly
payment on this loan is $41,400 monthly, plus interest. The
agency is current on this account, makes these payment timely
and has been paying $25,000 monthly on the principal.
As for a $58,762.00 amount seen/ referenced earlier in this report
with Administrator 2, this was a total amount owed/ paid toward
both of the Comerica Bank loans referenced above. A 3/31/2023
Wolverine automatic loan payment notice received from
Administrator 4 showed that amount to be the combined
due/payment related to $44,457.64 due for the principal and
$16,224.86 due for the interest on both Comerica Bank loans at
that time. Administrator 4 reported as of 4/11/2023 Wolverine’s
only loan with Comerica Bank is the one with the balance of
2,415,960 (Note # 000-0015-8).
7

Administrator 4 affirmed what was reported by COO 3 and
Administrator 2 as to the loan owed by Wolverine pertaining to the
WSTC building. That loan which had originated via Well-Fargo, is
the Investco lender account. It has a debt of $6,078,110 plus
interest. Administrator 4 advised that Wolverine defaulted on
that loan on 2/28/2021, after the WSTC facility closed, Wolverine
not having revenue to pay it. She also affirmed reports that the
agency was looking to sell the property; is in constant contact with
the lender; and people who may be looking to purchase it. She
said, the agency had a company from out of state looking at the
WSTC building as recent as March 2023.
Employee Interviews
On 4/17/2023 I interviewed seven of the agency employees, which
ended up consisting of staff from three of its four listed office sites.
The employees’ employment time with the agency ranged from
four months to eight years. Each of these employees reporting
was consist with those of caregivers with respect to them always
been paid timely and consistently. Each of these employees
reported receiving twice monthly payments by way of direct
deposit. Neither of these employees had experienced a late
payment or nonreceipt of a payment. All reported this agency as
a positive agency to work for, and one they would recommend.
Foster Care Providers Interviews
Starting on 4/17/2023 and ending on 4/18/2023 I interviewed nine
of the agency’s foster care caregivers by telephone. Five of
these caregivers were foster parents and four were unlicensed
relatives. I spoke with four licensed foster parents on 4/17/2023;
and a fifth licensed foster parent on 4/18/2023. The respective
caregiver’s length of time with the agency ranged from one year to
five years. With the exception of a couple of the caregivers
reporting there being a delay in them receiving an initial board and
care payment (that they later received back payments of; and
which they did not think was due to any fault of the agency’s), all
of the caregivers reported timely and consistent twice monthly
board and care payments from the agency. Many of these
providers did not know whether those payments were accurate,
but all reported the amounts seemed correct, and came regularly,
either by direct deposit or check.
Document Review:
A January 11, 2023, Memorandum from MDHHS’s Audit and
Review Section (ARS) which indicated Wolverine Human Services
per fiscal year ending 9/30/2021:
8

• Were found to have several financial risk factors.
• During fiscal year ended 9/30/2021, MDHHS provided the
agency: Foster care, State payments for 12, 401,762.
• The program areas that contract with Wolverine Human
Services should be aware of the following information noted
in the audit report:
➢ Working Capital-Wolverine Human Services has
negative working capital of $3,922,621 for 2021.
Working capital is a common measure of an
agency’s liquidity. Negative working capital generally
indicates an agency’s inability to pay off its short-
term liabilities if they came due immediately.
➢ Current Ratio-Wolverine Human Services has a
current Ratio of 0.63.1. Current ratio tests liquidity by
deriving the proportion of current assets available to
cover current liabilities. The higher the current ratio,
the more capable the agency is of paying its
obligations. A ratio under 1% suggests that the
agency could be unable to pay off its obligations if
they came due at that point.
➢ The audit report included relevant notes to the
financial statements. Notes 5 and 12 in the 2021
Financial Statement are attached.
➢ Note number 5 details that the agency defaulted on
a semi-annual payment for a Long-Term note. This
resulted in all Long-Term debt converting to current
debt. Current Debt due is $9,404,704.
➢ Note Number 12 details the Going Concern
Consideration. This note quantifies that without the
PPP (Paycheck Protection Program)proceeds, State
of Michigan grant, and ERC(Employee Retention
Credit) monies Wolverines Human Services current
year loss would have been approximately
($923,000). Those were all one-time funds, and the
note states those factors raise substantial doubt
about the Organization’s ability to continue as a
going concern.
• The ARS will continue to monitor the agency and provide
updates, as deemed necessary.
• Note 5 titled Note Payable and Long-Tern Debt from
Wolverine Human Services 9/30/2021 Financial Statement.
This note indicated Long-term debt consists of:
9

Mortgage payable-bank, 5.85% interest $6,078,110
with semi-annual of $568,434 through
August 2027.
Mortgage payable-bank 2.655% interest $2,886,242
with monthly payments of approximately
$30,100 through February 2030
Mortgage payable-bank 5.62% interest $ 344, 793
with monthly payments of $19,200
through May 2023.
Note payable-bank, 5.85% interest with $95,559
monthly payments of $6,755 through
October 2022
$9, 404,704
Less current portion $9,404,704
Total long-term debt $ -
• As a result of not paying the semi-annual payments of
$568,434, the Organization is in violations of certain
covenants. Accordingly, all long-term borrowings are due
currently.
Note 12 titled Going on Concern Consideration from Wolverine
Human Services 9/30/2021 Financial Statement. This note
indicated:
• During the year, the Organization closed its secure
treatment facility and is in default on that corresponding
debt of approximately $6.1 million. Other debts of
approximately $3.3 million is in violation of certain loan
agreements but is being serviced. Revenues decreased by
over 50% during the COVID-19 pandemic. Without the PPP
proceeds, $2,077,312, State grant, and the recoverable
ERC monies, the current year loss would have
approximated $923,000. Accordingly, management had
determined these factors raise substantial doubt about the
Organization’s ability to continue as a going concern.
• Subsequent to the year end, the Organization was awarded
a $3,5 million sustainability payment from the State of
Michigan, received approval for certain rate per diem
increases, and submitted for a $1.8 million refund as part of
the ERC payroll tax credit.
• Management believes with the $3.5 million sustainability
payment from the State of Michigan, in September 2022,
certain contractual per diem increases, adjusting the labor
levels to meet the client count, and potentially selling the
secure treatment facility, the Organization can achieve a
sustainable economic level.
10

• Management has concluded based on those factors the
Organization should be able to continue as a going
concern. The financial statement does not include any
adjustments that might be necessary should the
Organization not be able to continue as a going concern.
Wolverine Human Service’s Financial Statement for year ended
9/30/2020 which showed:
• Accommodations made, PPP loans, the agency had a
$1,000,000 available line of credit, principal payment on an
approximate $4.156 million long-term debt was deferred for
90 days. No financial covenants were violated during the
year.
• The compensation committee determined discretionary
funding of various insurance and mutual fund products to
satisfy the future obligation. During that current year the net
reserve decreased by approximately $390,000
• At 9/30/2020, the plan assets approximated $6.908 million,
and the estimated liability approximated $7, 054 million.
Comerica Bank loan payment notices: Advice of automatic loan
payments from 9/1/2021 to 4/3/2023 showing:
• In 2021 three notes/ accounts were being paid.
• The documents showed the principal balance, interest
rates, and amounts due. Reductions were seen on the
notices through the periods, as a result of the agency’s
payments on the principal and interest.
• As of 11/30/2022 loan note 000-00-00013- an interest due
of $55.69 was indicated. The loan was reported paid off.
• As of 3/31/2023 only loan note-000-00-0003-4 and note
000-00-0015-8 are listed on the payment notice.
• As of 4/11/2023 loan note 000-00-0003-4 had a zero
balance; it was paid off.
• As of 4/11/2023 loan note 000-00-0015-8, had a balance of
2,415,960.80.
A Wolverine Human Services ledgers showing:
• Lease payments, gas, electric payment for Warren, Taylor,
Bloomfield, Flint offices 10/1/2020- 3/17/2023 as noted for
the respective office.
Wolverine’s CPA- CM-465 form for 10/1/2020 to 9/30/2021
completed 12/31/2021 for contract number MA 2100809(adoption)
and MA1801004(foster care) showing:
11

• The CPA received adoption revenues of $534,896.00;
foster care funds of $3,449,907.20, for a total revenue of
$3,984,803.20.
• MDHHS board and care to foster parents was $1,471,913.
67 with that, mileage and other specific foster care
fundings totaling $1,682,479.00 for a total revenue of
$5,667, 282.20.
• Direct expenses paid by the CPA for salaries, fringe
benefits, operating cost, and foster care board payment
expenses was $5,394,204.85 with a revenue and expense
difference of $273,077.35.
Analysis The Organization’s larger outstanding debt of $ 6,078,110.37 and
secondary debt of $ 2,415,960.80 respectively are loans which
originated on residential facilities/CCI licenses outside of this
CPA’s specific license. The larger debt has been in default since
February 2021, after the Organization’s WSTC facility closed. The
agency maintains communication with that lender; and continues
efforts to either sell this property or develop a partnership to
develop another program for the building, which ever proves
viable and productive. The smaller debt relates to the
Organization’s Vassar residential facility, and the agency
continues to make monthly payment toward this debt.
Notwithstanding these debts, the agency/this CPA continues to
receive various foster care and other revenues and pays it
employees, caregivers and other financial obligations. There is
not clear evidence that the agency is financially unstable and
unable to pay or met its ongoing obligations.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the agency’s current licensing status is recommended.
______________________________________ May 6, 2023
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
12
